METHOD: Active visual surveys, such as transect walks and hand netting;
SURVEY AREA SIZE: Usually a transect line (10m wide, 10m high) surrounding a lake, pond or a river. Depending on the size of the lake, these transect lines are usually up to 500m long, but can be considerably longer.

METHOD: Other;
OTHER METHOD: Sweep netting, ring counts
SURVEY AREA SIZE: Sweep netting has no area but I would guesstimate that each sweep is 0.1 sq m and I usually would do 160 sweeps so 16 sq m.  Rings are 0.1 sq m and I usually use 30 so 3 sq m.
SURVEY DURATION:
160 sweeps = 30 min
30 rings (to collect data, not including ring deployment) = 15 min

METHOD: Active visual surveys, such as transect walks and hand netting;
SURVEY AREA SIZE: Visual assessments can be conducted on pollard walk transects for butterflies and day-flying moths. These are measured by amount of transects per area rather than a minimum size of an area. The UKBMS states that transects are typically 1km long, but this doesn't account for small sites or very large sites in a simple manner. In my experience, although dependent on the character/accessibility of the area questioned, a transect of 1k m in length is enough to capture the maximum species occupancy at a 3-5 ha site. There are further caveats to transect design beyond area though, including relative homogeneity of  a site. For example, a large species-poor grassland might not need the same survey effort as an equally sized structurally complex woodland with well managed rides, glades, shaded areas etc. Certainly under representing a site through poor transect to area ratio can potentially impact accuracy in abundance and diversity measurements, particularly where structure, habitat types and general character is diverse.
SURVEY DURATION:
Butterfly transect sampling season spans April to the end of September, with at least 26 visits to a site's transect in that period under specific weather conditions. This captures as much of each season as possible, including the June 'lull'. The amount of years sampled depends on the context of the study, but even relative comparisons between areas should aim to capture at least one of each season for a single year at the bare minimum. When comparing phenology, 3 - 5 + years could be considered the minimum to make any solid conclusions and account for any exceptional years such as the summer heatwave of 2022. 

If the question refers to how long an individual survey takes, butterfly pollard walk transects typically take 20+ minutes per 1km transect depending on the terrain. Other effective visual surveys include the 15 minute walk, but this is contextual depending on the area being surveyed and should supplement pollard walks, not replace them, and would be conducted as the same frequency as the pollard walk.

REGION: South Africa (particularly Succulent Karoo in the west of the country)
METHOD: Active visual surveys, such as transect walks and hand netting;
SURVEY AREA SIZE: Survey depends on the (very variable) flower display, flower diversity and opportunity in a semiarid environment; survey areas range from a few 100 m² to about a hectare.
SURVEY DURATION: Again, this depends on opportunity (usually suitable weather), structure of the site (floral display, size) and number of bees. Range is from 1 hour (small site, few flowers and bees) to about 8-10 hours on different days.

REGION: I have been studying the Central and South America caddisfly fauna for the past 15 years. However, my main focus for the past 5 years is the Trichoptera fauna in the Amazon Rainforest.
METHOD: Light trapping;Malaise trapping;Active visual surveys, such as transect walks and hand netting;
SURVEY AREA SIZE: Each field trip works on an average area of 400 square kilometers. The collecting methods are implemented along the margin of preserved streams and rivers (preferentially). My team usually explores around 80 square meters by day with the three methods listed above.
SURVEY DURATION: Each field trip lasts approximately 7-10 days, sampling one or two streams (distant at least 10km from each other) by day. Sampling starts around 2pm with active entomological nets by the stream margin as well as active immature search in the stream. Around 6pm active search stops, light traps are set up and sampling goes until 10pm. So, it is a 4-hour active search and 4-hour light trap sampling per day along 7-10 days.

SURVEY AREA SIZE:
adults & exuviae - stream/river segments (~100m each), pond perimeters (length depends on pond size), wetland vegetated areas (meandering searches)  
nymphs (lentic waters) - 5 1-m sweeps at netting stations (3 minimum, dependent on area) at least 10 m apart along littoral macrophyte beds (ponds/lakes) or scattered across inundated wetland vegetation zones
SURVEY DURATION:
adults: 20-40 minutes every 2-3 weeks
exuviae: 30 minutes every 2-3 weeks
nymphs: 2-5 collection events during May to September

METHOD: Active visual surveys, such as transect walks and hand netting;Beating sheet;Light trapping;Other;
SURVEY AREA SIZE:
This will depend a great deal on the experimental design.
For suction sampling, I would take a series of 10 sub-samples equivalent to 0.2m2, which would constitute a single sample. Then a series of samples would be taken; 3, 5 or 10 per location, depending on the aim of the project. If a treatment comparison was being made, then the number of samples might be 3 or 5 per replicate treatment. If the aim was to gain species list then a larger number of samples would be taken (20-100+), ideally over a period of weeks and months, to take account of phenological changes.
Tree beating - I would select four points on a given tree and hold a net (approx 50 x 50 cm) under a suitable branch, then shake/beat vigorously for 1 minute.
Sweep netting - using a figure of 8 sweeping technique, I would take a sample base on 20 back and forth motions, whilst walking forward. The exact area sampled is hard to quantify accurately (although it can be estimated). Each would be a sample and I would apply the same number of samples as for suction sampling, above.
Light trapping - impossible to know the area of sampling.
SURVEY DURATION:
Light trapping - typically I would run a light trap for 3-4 hours, and then spend 2 hours collecting.
Tree beating, sweep netting and suction sampling would all be done on a regular basis over a period of weeks, and preferably months. Depending of logistical constraints, such as travel to and between locations, I would sample 1 or two days per week. In the UK I would do so from start of April to end of Sept, to take account of phenological changes.

METHOD: Beating sheet;Acoustic monitoring;Active visual surveys, such as transect walks and hand netting;
SURVEY AREA SIZE:
beating (for Orthoptera nymphs and earwigs) a total of 30 minutes at each site, 40 locations beaten in this time roughly, each location 5 strikes of a branch or foliage. 

Gardiner T (2010) Hedgerow species richness influences the presence of Orthoptera and Dermaptera along green lanes in Essex, U.K. Entomologist’s Gazette 61: 53–64.

acoustic monitoring and visual surveys (Orthoptera):  A 1-m wide × 400-m long transect was established in fields in recent study. Transects were arranged in a W shape (each arm 100 m) to ensure even coverage of each field and avoid any edge habitat effects. Each transect was walked at a slow, strolling pace (2 km/hr) on 3 occasions from May–August 2021. Adult individuals of all Orthoptera species along all transects were recorded acoustically and visually to determine assemblage composition and species diversity and richness. Nymphs flushed from a 1-m wide band in front of the observer were recorded along all transects. As it is difficult to distinguish between species in the early instars (though not impossible, see Thommen 2021), numbers for nymphs of all species were lumped together for recording purposes. The surveys were undertaken in vegetation sufficiently short (<50 cm) to minimize the possibility of overlooking nymphs in tall grass or non-stridulating species such as groundhoppers (Tetrigidae). With practice, it was relatively easy to ascertain the species of adults without capture (Gardiner and Hill 2006), although some species, such as long-winged conehead Conocephalus fuscus and Roesel’s bushcricket Roeseliana roeselii, are significantly under-recorded using visual transects. A dual visual and acoustic monitoring method has been used by Weiss et al. (2013) to ensure complete coverage of the orthopteran fauna of sites. In the current study, a stridulation monitoring technique was used to record adult males of species that stridulated along the transects at the same time as visual monitoring by flushing. Stridulation monitoring has been used to record cryptic species in Essex and has been found to be effective compared to visual sighting transects and pitfall traps. Bat detectors were not required in the current study as the surveyor was able to reliably detect stridulating males up to 20 m away either side of the transect. The weather conditions on survey days were favourable for insect activity, being largely sunny and warm (>17°C). 

Gardiner T, Casey D (2022) ﻿Orthoptera in the early stages of post-arable rewilding in south-east England. Journal of Orthoptera Research 31(2): 163-172. https://doi.org/10.3897/jor.31.82317

visual surveys (Hymenoptera)

Bumblebee monitoring: In sea wall grasslands, 100 m long x 6 m wide transects were established. The methodology for surveying bumblebees followed that of Carvell et al. (2007). Surveys were undertaken between 10:00 and 17:00 h, when weather conditions conformed to the
following criteria for the UK Butterfly Monitoring Scheme: 1) transects were not walked when the temperature is below 13°C; 2) between 13-17 °C, a transect could be walked providing there is at least 60% sun; 3) above 17 °C, a transect could be walked in any conditions, providing it is not raining; 4) when wind speeds are above 5 on the Beaufort scale, transects were not walked (Pollard & Yates 1993).

Gardiner T. & Fargeaud K. (2018) The effect of late cutting on bumblebees (Bombus spp.) in sea wall
grassland. Aspects of Applied Biology, 139, 43-50.
SURVEY DURATION:
beating: 30 minutes per site 
acoustic and visual surveys: 2-3 hours at each site in the different habitats. Depends on complexity of site.

REGION: Europe New Zealand, Australia, Pacific Islands.
METHOD: Beating sheet;Malaise trapping;Light trapping;Pan trapping;Pitfall trapping;Active visual surveys, such as transect walks and hand netting;
SURVEY AREA SIZE:
Malaise trapping: (usually limited by the availability of traps)1 trap per 1000 sq m.
Light trapping: (usually limited by the availability of traps) 1 trap per 1000 sq m.
Pan trapping: 3-4 traps per 100 sq m.
Pitfall trapping: 3-4 traps per 100 sq m.
Beating sheet: usually sampling each different plant within an area.
Visual surveys: 1 plant every 3 per orchard.
SURVEY DURATION:
Malaise trapping: leave the trap out for 1 week. Repeat x2 or x3 times a year depending on seasonality.
Light trapping: 3-5 hours per night. Ideally multiple nights per week. Repeat depending on seasonality.
Pan trapping: leave the traps out for 1 week. Repeat depending on seasonality.
Pitfall trapping: leave the traps out for 1 week. Repeat depending on seasonality.
Beating sheet: 2 or 3 branches per plant, about 20 minutes in total per plant.
Visual surveys: 2 or 3 branches per plant, about 10 minutes per plant.

METHOD: Other;
OTHER METHOD: Bottle traps and handnetting for aquatic insects.
SURVEY AREA SIZE:
Pools/ponds/lakes vary a lot in size. The wetlands I survey are usually 60m2 - 15000m2 (1.5 hectares). 

Bottle traps usually are placed a few meters apart from each other, but it is very difficult to say the unit a bottle trap can survey, because the home range of aquatic insects is unknown. 

For handnetting, one can choose multiple 1m2 quadrats to survey.
SURVEY DURATION: For bottle traps, I usually leave the traps in water for 48 hours. For handnetting, I usually swipe the water and vegetation for 1 minute.

METHOD: Other;
OTHER METHOD: Flight-interception and multi-funnel traps
SURVEY AREA SIZE: Around 7 hectares
SURVEY DURATION: Our traps were hung in trees for months, approxymately from April/May to September. So around 5 months.

METHOD: Pitfall trapping;
SURVEY AREA SIZE: 50 x 50 m plots with four traps, one in each corner. The area really depends on the project, 5 replicate 50 x 50 m plots should be the minimum
SURVEY DURATION: 48-72 hours

METHOD: Other;Pan trapping;

METHOD: Active visual surveys, such as transect walks and hand netting;Light trapping;
SURVEY AREA SIZE: 1-5 square kilometres on average, though highly variable
SURVEY DURATION: Taxon & aim-dependent, but average 4-8 days (butterflies) or nights (light-trapping moths).

METHOD: Light trapping;Active visual surveys, such as transect walks and hand netting;
SURVEY AREA SIZE: 15,000 square meters for line transect, 2800 square meters for light trapping
SURVEY DURATION: 30 min for line transect, 5 hours for light trapping

METHOD: Other;
OTHER METHOD: Checklist surveys as in Royer and Malone (1998). Very similar to "active visual surveys, such as transect walks and hand netting" and typical Pollard-Yates, but instead that meandering is permitted (Royer, R.A., Austin, J.E. and Newton, W.E. 1998. Checklist and “Pollard Walk” Butterfly Survey Methods on Public Lands. The American Midland Naturalist, 140: 358–371. University of Notre Dame.)
SURVEY AREA SIZE: Depends on size of supportive Lepidopteran habitat, and whether surveying for adults or larvae. For adults, typically an average of 4.75 km long (x 5 m observations on both sides = approximately 0.05 km2) to cover 1.75 km2. For surveys where larvae were the focus, and I watched for adults while walking between larval host plants, an average of 1.25 km long covering an area of around 0.25 km2.
SURVEY DURATION: Again, depends on size of supportive Lepidopteran habitat, and whether surveying for adults or larvae. Given the same parameters as above: for adults during one survey excursion, typically 1 hr, and for larvae, typically 0.75 hrs. Typically, I survey the same places between 1-3 times during their anticipated flight period.

METHOD: Malaise trapping;Active visual surveys, such as transect walks and hand netting;
SURVEY AREA SIZE:
For Malaise traps: typically two Gressit & Gressit style Malaise traps are erected in study area, spaced at least 100m away from each other if possible, sometimes much further depending on accessibility. The sampling surface area, in this case the vertical flight interception area for each trap would be approx. 5.4 m2

For sweepnetting/handnetting one typically "surveys" around one self for about 2 m in each direction, walking about 50 meters at a time before emptying the net into aspirators, so an estimated 100 m2 per "transect". The number of transects would depend on the distance covered, and again accessibility.
SURVEY DURATION:
Handnetting: approx. 4 hours a day

Malaise traps are left up for the duration of being at the study area. 2-7 days. Specimens are not collected in ethanol but pinned and processed in the field. Diptera families typically preserved in ethanol, eg. Cecidomyiidae, Psychodidae are stored as such.

REGION:
Malaysia (dung beetles, Odonata, Lepidoptera), Indonesia (Odonanta, dung beetles), Singapore (dung beetles, Odonata, Lepidoptera), Philippines (butterflies)
UK (dung beetles, Lepidoptera), Finland (dung beetles)
METHOD: Light trapping;Pitfall trapping;Active visual surveys, such as transect walks and hand netting;Other;
OTHER METHOD: Butterfly fruit baited traps; in temperate regions hand search pats for dung beetles and also can use flotation method
SURVEY AREA SIZE:
It depends on the question.
For dung beetles and butterfly fruit traps we set 10 traps 100-200m apart along transect lines, but other surveys have used fractal designs e.g. SAFE.
For Odonata we follow standard protocols for surveying water bodies in an area for a set period of time so not area based per se.
Butterflies usually use the Pollard walk method along a e.g. 500m/1km transect depending on the area size.
for moths I have most frequently used actinic traps and we have shown they can have an attraction radius of around 30m so I would make sure that traps were set at least 50m-100m apart but numbers depends on area size/question.
SURVEY DURATION:
For dung beetles trap is set for 48h. Ideally would repeat this at least twice a year in tropics (wet/dry) but obviously more regular monthly/bimonthly sampling would be good for monitoring

Butterfly traps 24 hours
Actinic moth traps set at dusk, collect just after sunrise
Odonata - standardized search times at water bodies - depends on surveys - e.g. 15 minutes. Should be repeated over multiple days/times of year ideally.

METHOD: Malaise trapping;Light trapping;Other;
OTHER METHOD: Aquatic kick sampling
SURVEY AREA SIZE:
Aquatic kick sampling - 3 minute kick sample of major sub-habitats at a site followed by 1 minute of active searching. 
Light trapping - deployment of light traps on banks of waterbodies. Usually left for a couple of hours at dusk with specimens of mayflies/stoneflies/caddisflies collected
Malaise trapping - not generally used as too much collateral material. Typically left on site for a week or longer.
SURVEY DURATION:
Aquatic kick sampling - 3 minutes plus 1 minute active sampling
Light trapping - 2 hours
Malaise trapping - 1 week to several months.

SURVEY AREA SIZE: Winkler bags 1 square metre of sieved litter, very variable for the others.
SURVEY DURATION: This largely depends on funds and logistics but Malaise, pan and pitfall traps I usually keep out for one week.

METHOD: Malaise trapping;Pitfall trapping;Active visual surveys, such as transect walks and hand netting;Other;
OTHER METHOD: Winkler extractor, Baiting, hand collection with forceps, and entomological aspirator
SURVEY AREA SIZE:
winkler - 1m2 sample in 100m, 200m or 1 km transects/site  - depends on the size area
pitfall traps - 200 ml cup in 100 m, 200m or a 1 km transects/site  - depends of the size area
Malaise, baiting, hand collection, and others - depends of the size area and the goal
SURVEY DURATION:
pitfall traps - usually 24h, 48h or five days
winkler  - after litter extracted, samples are hanging for around 24h or 48h.
Malaise - 2 or 4 days or a week
hand collection with forceps and entomological aspirator - depends the size of the area and the goal. Sometimes a 1 hour/site. If looking for a specific specie sometimes the whole day.

REGION: Brazil and United States - but also have some experience collecting ants in Peru, Venezuela, Nicaragua, and Germany

METHOD: Active visual surveys, such as transect walks and hand netting;
SURVEY AREA SIZE:
Semi-quantantive surveys:
a. 300-m Pollard walks for butterflies, i.e. 300*5=1500 m2 
b. 10x10m quadrats for orthoptera, i.e. 100 m2 
Surveys for rare species:
c. (time constrained) active sampling in suitable habitats, equaling ca. 50-100 m2
SURVEY DURATION:
a. Butterfly transects: ca. 30 min
b. Orthoptera quadrats: ca. 30 min
c. Active visual surveys for rare species: ca. 60 min

METHOD: Malaise;Pitfall;Outros - Especificar;
OTHER METHOD:
Nossa principal técnica de coleta é o extrator de serapilheira do tipo mini-Winkler para a coleta de formigas epigeicas em áreas de florestas. Para maiores informações sobre esta técnica, por favor, consulte a referência abaixo:

Bestelmeyer, B.T.; Agosti, D.; Alonso, L.E.; Brandão, C.R.F.; Brown Jr.; W.L.; Delabie, J.H.C. & Silvestre, R. 2000. Field techniques for the study of ground-dwelling ants. In: Agosti, D.; Majer, J.D.; Tennant de Alonso, L. & Schultz, T. (Eds.), Measuring and monitoring biological diversity: standard methods for ground living ants Smithsonian Institution Press, Washington, p.122144. Disponível em: http://antbase.org/ants/publications/20330/20330.pdf
SURVEY AREA SIZE:
A escala regional varia muito dependendo dos objetivos do levantamento. Usualmente trabalhamos com 60 armadilhas do tipo pitfall (copos de 275 ml) divididas em 3 transectos de 500 metros (20 pitfalls por transecto separadas por 25 metros). Por sua vez os transectos são afastados 1km entre si.

Para a técnica de Winkler normalmente coletamos amostras de serapilheira de 1m2 cobrindo a mesma área das armadilhas do tipo pitfall.
SURVEY DURATION: As armadilhas Malaise ficam expostas em média por 4 dias. Para as armadilhas do tipo pitfall o tempo de exposição é de 48hs. A coleta de formigas de serapilheira com o extrator de Winkler acontece em tempo real.

METHOD: Autre - Veuillez préciser;
OTHER METHOD: Pitfall traps, lavage du sol, tamisage de litière, recherche active sous les pierres, dans le bois, ...
SURVEY AREA SIZE:
Pifall traps : 1 piège par m2. 100 pièges par site = unité de 10000 m2
Lavage du sol : 10 échantillons par site = 400 m2 
Tamisage de litière : 20 échantillons par site = 400 m2 
Recherche active (sous les pierres, le bois, ...) : 1000 m2 par
SURVEY DURATION:
Pifall traps : 1 Unité par jour (les pièges reste sur place pour une semaine)
Lavage du sol : 1 unité pat jour
Tamisage de litière : 20 échantillons par site = 400 m2  unité par jour 
Recherche active (sous les pierres, le bois, ...) : 2 unités par jours
